author: Mary Harris
title: Northern Lights visible over Kent last night - take a look at readers' stunning photos - Kent Live
text:
frontpage News Kent News Best of Kent Northern Lights visible over Kent last night - take a look at readers' stunning photos It was an absolutely spectacular sight
Bookmark
Share
Comments News By Mary Harris 11:36, 11 OCT 2024 Updated 11:59, 11 OCT 2024 Bookmark
Naomi Nixon captured this stunning photo from Greatstone Beach (Image: Naomi Nixon) Nature put on a spectacular light show with the Northern Lights and Kent residents wasted no time capturing the stunning sight. People across the county have been awestruck by the swirling colours in the clear night sky last night (October 10).
Northern Lights, also called Aurora Borealis, are so breathtaking because they have magnificent colours of green, pink, violet, red and blue. Social media - and the KentLive mail box - are full of photos of the natural illuminations.
People get so excited in this part of the world not only because of the sheer multi-coloured splendour of the skies, but because they are seen only occasionally over the country. According to the Met Office , Northern Lights happen because of "solar activity and result from collisions of charged particles in the solar wind colliding with molecules in the Earth's upper atmosphere".
The reason we are seeing them, according to the Met Office, is because there had been “more space weather events in recent months”, including the Northern Lights, because the sun was nearing the peak of its solar cycle. And you might be looking over your fantastic photos rather than seeing it again tonight, as the Met Office says: "The chances of aurora remain initially, though gradually easing through October 11, becoming increasingly confined to far northern geomagnetic latitudes by October 13."
Take a look at readers' incredible photos of Thursday's Northern Lights display below.
Darren Gregory sent us this lovely shot from Westbrook in Margate
